trans-unit.source: Create a Windows virtual machine with Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create a Windows virtual machine with Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Use the Resource Management mode of Azure PowerShell to easily create a new Windows virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Use the Resource Management mode of Azure PowerShell to easily create a new Windows virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Create a Windows virtual machine with Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create a Windows virtual machine with Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to quickly create a Windows-based Azure virtual machine using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to quickly create a Windows-based Azure virtual machine using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Create a Windows virtual machine with PowerShell and Azure Service Management
trans-unit.target: Create a Windows virtual machine with PowerShell and Azure Service Management

trans-unit.source: Create the Windows virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Create the Windows virtual machine

trans-unit.source: If you have already installed Azure PowerShell, you must have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: If you have already installed Azure PowerShell, you must have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't done so already or need to update the version of Azure PowerShell installed, use the instructions in [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](install-configure-powershell.md) to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't done so already or need to update the version of Azure PowerShell installed, use the instructions in [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](install-configure-powershell.md) to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Then, open an Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Then, open an Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: First, you must logon to Azure with this command.
trans-unit.target: First, you must logon to Azure with this command.

trans-unit.source: Specify the email address of your Azure account and its password in the Microsoft Azure sign-in dialog.
trans-unit.target: Specify the email address of your Azure account and its password in the Microsoft Azure sign-in dialog.

trans-unit.source: Next, if you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you need to set your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Next, if you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you need to set your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of your current subscriptions, run this command.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of your current subscriptions, run this command.

trans-unit.source: Now, replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct subscription name and run these commands.
trans-unit.target: Now, replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct subscription name and run these commands.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to create a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to create a storage account.

trans-unit.source: You must pick a unique name that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.
trans-unit.target: You must pick a unique name that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.

trans-unit.source: You can test for the uniqueness of the storage account name with this command.
trans-unit.target: You can test for the uniqueness of the storage account name with this command.

trans-unit.source: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.
trans-unit.target: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.

trans-unit.source: You will need to specify the location of an Azure datacenter.
trans-unit.target: You will need to specify the location of an Azure datacenter.

trans-unit.source: To get a list of Azure datacenters, run this command.
trans-unit.target: To get a list of Azure datacenters, run this command.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to switch the mode of Azure PowerShell to Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to switch the mode of Azure PowerShell to Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Run this command.
trans-unit.target: Run this command.

trans-unit.source: Now, copy the following block of PowerShell commands to a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Now, copy the following block of PowerShell commands to a text editor.

trans-unit.source: Fill in your chosen storage account and location, replacing everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters.
trans-unit.target: Fill in your chosen storage account and location, replacing everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters.

trans-unit.source: Finally, copy the above command set to the clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Finally, copy the above command set to the clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This will issue the command set as a series of PowerShell commands, prompt you for the name and password of the local administrator account, and create your Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This will issue the command set as a series of PowerShell commands, prompt you for the name and password of the local administrator account, and create your Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.target: Here is an example of you might see:
